    Version:
    2019-12 (4.14.0) Console User Interface (UI) class Uses Scanner class for inputs

    Ryan Clinton

      private void addCustomFilter()

        holds user selection

      • scanner

        java.util.Scanner scanner
        Scanner object for inputs

      • filters

        Kernel[] filters
        Array of Kernel objects for our filters. Instantiated at start of constructor. I used array instead of ArrayList or something because I only added custom filters right at the end. I figure it's a rare enough to add them that it's not egregious; but I would have changed it if I had time.

    • Constructor Detail

      • UI

        public UI()
        Constructor - Loads in filters and handles main menu

    • Method Detail

      • addCustomFilter

        private void addCustomFilter()
        This method gets inputs from the user for a custom filter, then instantiates it and adds it to the array supports 3x3 and 5x5 Code is a bit of a mess because I was running out of time and making silly mistakes, which I covered up with messy code

      • displayMainMenu

        private void displayMainMenu()
        Prints the main menu options.

      • getDefaultFilters

        private Kernel[] getDefaultFilters()
        Returns a list of pre-set kernels from the brief. If more are added here later, the filter selection menu will dynamically present them and allow them to be selected. Called on start-up
        Returns:
        array of pre-set kernels

      • displayFilterMenu

        private void displayFilterMenu()
        Dynamically lists filters and allows user to select one. This includes the presets, and any custom filters that the user has created.
